DOC.HEAD: Party Fails to Reach Agreement on How to Deal with Lithuanian Schism
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party leadership met Monday but failed to agree on how to deal with the Lithuanian party's unprecedented declaration of independence from the Kremlin, a source said. The source, one of the more than 250 members of the party's policy-making Central Committee, said the committee would resume its plenary meeting on the question Tuesday. ``They decided to think it over and start again,'' said the high-ranking party official, who spoke on condition he not be identified. Lithuanian Communists voted Wednesday at a special congress in their capital of Vilnius to form their own party, rejecting appeals for unity from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other top Soviet officials. The Lithuanians' break is serious because it is without precedent in the history of the party founded by Vladimir I. Lenin, who demanded and forged a unitary party across the Soviet Union. Moreover, Lithuanian reformers predict local party organizations in many of the other 14 constituent Soviet republics will rapidly follow their example, which would present Gorbachev with a fractured party as he prepares for a nationwide party congress in October 1990. The Central Committee convened in Moscow on Monday ``to consider the situation in the Lithuanian party branch,'' state-run Radio Moscow said. Other official media did not immediately report on the closed-door session. Algirdas Brazauskas, the Lithuanian party leader, said the break, which included drafting a separate party program, was necessary for Lithuanian Communists to compete successfully in local elections Feb. 24. However, a group of Lithuanian Communists who opposed the break countered by forming their own leadership, and pledged continuing loyalty to Moscow. The Central Committee invited both Brazauskas and the leaders of the anti-separatist faction to Moscow to attend its meeting, Radio Moscow said.
